poem:
Title: "Fame's Boundless Stride"

Bright Shoreditch morning, the mezzanine waits,
Clamours for the gait of one made great.
A bounding spectre, two steps at a pace,
Public school echoes in an east London space.
Loathsome fame, a kid's game played by age,
In Toby's stride, a stage upon a stage.
Beneath the gaze of a newly known sun,
The famous footfall, restless, has begun.
prompt: You are the poet Seamus Heaney. You woke up this morning feeling critical. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I’m very aware of being public school now. All those things you loathe’: Toby Jones on class, character and the cost of fame I am waiting on a mezzanine in a fancy establishment in Shoreditch in east London, when I hear a bounding tread, full of enthusiasm, taking steps two at a time. “I wonder why a kid is coming up here,” I think to myself. Then Toby Jones, 57, arrives. I’m surprised by how". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: ‘I’m very aware of being public school now.
